justification: The article states that “Participants are asked to provide probability judgments,” indicating that the construct of probability judgment is operationalised by having people give a numerical probability rating.
It notes that participants give “estimates of physical quantities,” showing that the construct (estimating a quantity) is measured by the numeric estimate people report.
The text refers to estimates “with associated confidence intervals,” meaning the degree of confidence is captured by the interval limits the participant supplies.

measured_by: selection of an option (binary or multi-alternative choice)
justification: The passage describes asking participants to make “choices” such as deciding whether a number is above or below a boundary, so the choice selected serves as the measure of this construct.
Choices are said to have “their associated response times,” explicitly identifying elapsed decision time as the measure for response speed.
The article states it is possible to “elicit their confidence rating for either of these responses,” showing that subjective confidence is measured through a rating scale.
